thread.title: The good and the bad from Week 7: MAC Football 2015
thread.title_full: The good and the bad from Week 7: MAC Football 2015

author: Plain Dealer Sports
title: The good and the bad from Week 7: MAC Football 2015
text:
Comments 
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- While one team (Toledo) continued to climb, another (Kent State) used some fresh faces to get on track in Week 7 of MAC Football 2015. 
Youth was served: Kent State redshirt freshman George Bollas made his first start at quarterback for the Golden Flashes and while his numbers didn't overwhelm, his efficiency was key in leading a 15-10 win over UMass. 
Bollas, the former Aurora High School standout, completed 20-of-25 passes for 135 yards and one touchdown with one interception, a Hail Mary toss at the end of the first half. He also ran 15 times for 79 yards. 
And in his first game as the primary ballcarrier, freshman Raekwon James carried 20 times for 85 yards and caught eight passes for 56 yards. 
Another freshman, Shane Hynes, kicked a pair of field goals. 
The KSU defense shut down UMass QB Blake Frohnapfel, recording seven sacks including a safety, and next will get to test itself against the high-powered Bowling Green offense on Saturday. 
Getting his kicks: Kent State senior punter Anthony Melchiori (Aurora) had four straight impressive punts during the fourth quarter of Kent State's win. With his back foot just inside the back line of his end zone, Melchiori booted a 55-yard punt early in the fourth quarter. His next three punts were downed on the UMass 1-, 9- and 2-yard lines, respectively. In the first three quarters, Melchiori's punts included a 54-yarder and a pair of fair catches inside the 20. 
On the rise: Toledo climbed to No. 19 in this week's Associated Press Top 25 poll, the highest the Rockets have been ranked since 1997 when they reached No. 18 for a week. The best ever for Toledo was No. 12 in the final poll of 1970. 
The Rockets pounded Eastern Michigan on Saturday, 63-20, despite being kept off the board in the first quarter. It was a season-high point total for Toledo, as QB Phillip Ely threw for 327 yards and four touchdowns. 
Toledo (6-0, 3-0) plays at UMass (1-5, 0-2) on Saturday. 
Defense rests: It was a long day for the Ohio Bobcats defensive unit in Saturday's 49-14 loss to Western Michigan. 
OU allowed a season-high 567 yards of total offense, including 430 on the ground. Two Broncos topped 100 yards rushing â€“ LeVante Bellamy had 149 on nine carries and Jamauri Bogan had 135 on nine carries -- and Jarvion Franklin finished with 95 yards on 13 carries. WMU averaged 9.8 yards per carry. Ohio had allowed just one 100-yard game this season.
